text.headline: Sherwood Anderson, circa 1924-1940
text.text:
A novelist, essayist, and poet, Sherwood Anderson is best known for Winesburg, Ohio (1917), his collection of interrelated short stories set in a fictional midwestern town. With its examination of small-town inhabitants "adrift on the flatlands of the Midwest, each of them in their own way struggling — and failing — to locate meaning, personal connection and love amid the town’s elm-shaded streets," Anderson's writing captured societal unease as America shifted from an agrarian to an industrial economy.

Personal connection didn't seem to be a problem for the author, whose intimate correspondence with friends and family tracks his four marriages, mental health struggles, and growing interest in Communist ideology and workers' rights. Join his emotional and geographic journey via these excerpts, courtesy of our volunteers at Newberry Transcribe.

text.headline: Too bad for Tennessee, 1924
text.text:
Chicago, Sept. 20, 1924

Tennessee is pretty well. It's too damn bad she has to go to work teaching because she married me who won't settle down and support a woman as a respectable man should.

text.headline: I hate Christmas, 1930
text.text:
Marion, Virginia, Dec. 25, 1930:

I hate Christmas...

I went to Pat Pallin's new house. They have a 2 year old child - little Pat. Some one, Henry Staley perhaps, have given him a mechanical toy. He went up to it and kicked it to smitherines. 

Just then - I had to hold myself back. I said nothing. I wanted to say - "kick the goddam thing again."

text.headline: A dead bleak place, 1931
text.text:
Marion, Virginia, Feb. 2, 1931:

I have been in a dead bleak place again. They are like bad air pockets. Down and down you sink. I've never been able to figure them out. There is a kind of flight you try to maintain. How difficult it is...

I need man's friendship too, of a kind I can't get here and that I imagine you can't get there. It leaves a big hole, not having it.

text.headline: Something personal, 1932
text.text:
Apr. 25, 1932:

There is something personal. There is a woman here with whom I am in love.

It is not known that I am in love with her. She is a working woman, concerned now with women and girls in factories. At present she has a job in the industrial department of a philanthropic organization. She is about 35, rather small and dark, with a big head, like your own child and with eyes like your child.

text.headline: The great evil, 1932
text.text:
New York City, May 1932:

I'm becoming more and more a communist. I think it must be coming nearer - an inevitable thing...

I'm pretty sure money is the great evil. You get it and it separates you - at once from life. We are all cramped, hurt, all the time, by what goes on. How can art flourish. I'll tell you Charles, if the Russians pull it off - you'll see - some day a flowering there. Think of a whole nation of people who can be sure of work - the old and the sick and the weary decently taken care of - the land belonging to the state - the factories belonging to the state... Its worth fighting for - the beginning of it. It's worth any price.

text.headline: In love with America, 1933
text.text:
Kansas City, Missouri, Jan. 20, 1933:

I am writing from Kansas City - from a little rather tough hotel, full of little actors, prize fighters - auto salesmen out of work and whores - also out of work...

I got into the car and lit out - to drift for a time. I had a grand ride, over mountains and rivers and out onto the prairies - crossed the Cumberland, Tennessee, Ohio, Mississippi and Missouri Rivers. It rained, the wind blew, the sun shone. Again I got in love with America. What a land - O Charles - if we can but begin to love it and treat it devoutly some day. It is so violent and huge and gorgeous and rich and willing to be loved...

text.headline: A sad Christmas, 1940
text.text:
Knoxville, Tennessee, Dec. 28, 1940:

We came home to a sad Christmas.  Eleanor's mother, a very beautiful and remarkable woman, we all loved, had been found dead in her bed. It is a grand way to die and she was old and tired but something inside her never had tired.  Her death wrecked us.

Monte dear, your confession of love is the finest Christmas gift I could have.  I shall hang it up on a peg in my inner mind.
